description.narrative: Core support to Geneva Call, a neutral and impartial NGO dedicated to promoting respect by armed non-State actors for international humanitarian law. GC focuses on banning the use of anti-personnel mines, protecting children in armed conflict (especially preventing the recruitment of children in hostilities) as well as prohibiting sexual violence in conflict.

Geneva Call är en icke-vinstdrivande icke-statlig organisation som är verksam i cirka 20 länder inom fyra tematiska områden: baserat på internationell humanitär rätt skyddas civilbefolkningen i väpnad konflikt med fokus på skydd från land minor, skydd av barn, kvinnor, och kunskapsökning kring humanitära normer.

sector.narrative: Civilian peace-building, conflict prevention and resolution

Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2016Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: In 2016, Geneva Call worked in 14 contexts, where it engaged with 61 active armed non-State actors on the respect of humanitarian norms. The organisation also reached more than 12 million people with its Fighter not Killer media campaign on humanitarian norms in Iraq, Syria and the DRC. Geneva Call uses a variety of methods to raise awareness, knowledge and commitment on International Humanitarian Law among Armed Non-state Actors (ANSA's) with the aim to contribute to improved protection of civilians from the effects of armed conflict. In 2016, Geneva Call trained 3,321 leaders, fighters, trainers and representatives from local communities or authorities including 811 women on humanitarian norms through 132 training sessions and workshops. It also organised an ANSA meeting on the protection of children in armed conflict and 31 leaders, commanders and advisers from 21 armed movements from 12 countries in Geneva.
In 2016, One additional ANSA – the People's Defence Forces/Kurdistan Worker's Party (HPG/PKK) in Turkey – signed the Deed of Commitment prohibiting sexual violence and against gender discrimination, bringing the total number of active signatories to 16. Two ANSAs - the Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo (APCLS) in the DRC and the Zomi Revolutionary Organisation (ZRO) in India - signed the Deed of Commitment on child protection, bringing the number of active signatories to 19. Furthermore, Geneva Call actively monitors signatory ANSA's compliance with the deeds of commitment, and requests regular reporting from ANSAs on implementation measures (such as dissemination of the norms, training sessions, enforcement measures and cooperation in mine action). For example in Syria, The people’s protection Units (YPG/YPJ) continued to comply with the Deed of Commitment on land mines. The Democratic Self-Administration established a de-mining organisation which reportedly de-mined more than 90,000 AP mines in the area under the control of the YPG/YPJ.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
